articles.headline: House Approves Tougher Rules on Wall Street
articles.snippet: A regulatory overhaul meant to address what supporters call underlying causes of the financial crisis has yet to pass the Senate.
articles.abstract: A regulatory overhaul meant to address what supporters call underlying causes of the financial crisis has yet to pass the Senate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The House approved a Democratic plan on Friday to tighten federal regulation of Wall Street and banks, advancing a far-reaching Congressional response to the financial crisis that rocked the economy.

articles.headline: Redeem All of Gift Card, or Give Store a Present
articles.snippet: Major retailers and banks often profit from unspent portions of gift cards, but consumers don’t seem to notice.
articles.abstract: Major retailers and banks often profit from unspent portions of gift cards, but consumers don’t seem to notice.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like it or not, gift cards are now a fixture of the holiday season. And this year, some of the changes in the card world seem favorable at first glance.

articles.headline: Violence Grips South Sudan as Vote Nears
articles.snippet: With a referendum on independence planned, over 2,000 people have been killed in southern Sudan this year.
articles.abstract: With a referendum on independence planned, over 2,000 people have been killed in southern Sudan this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUK PADIET, Sudan  The word went out on a Friday. Chibetek was coming, with warriors and a grudge to settle.

articles.headline: P.& G. Sees the World as Its Client
articles.snippet: With new leadership, the consumer products giant wants to start winning over new customers in places like Nigeria, India and Somalia.
articles.abstract: With new leadership, the consumer products giant wants to start winning over new customers in places like Nigeria, India and Somalia.
articles.lead_paragraph: Add close to 548,000 new customers a day.

articles.headline: The Lure of Store Credit Cards, and the Hook
articles.snippet: A 15 percent discount, or no interest payments for 18 months, sounds enticing, but there are some other things you need to know about store-brand credit cards.
articles.abstract: A 15 percent discount, or no interest payments for 18 months, sounds enticing, but there are some other things you need to know about store-brand credit cards.
articles.lead_paragraph: You may be tempted this season to give in to the plea from that persistent sales clerk at one of the big retailers  “Are you sure you don’t want to save 15 percent today?”  and open up a couple of store-brand credit cards. After all, a 15 percent discount, or no interest payments for 18 months, sounds enticing when you are buying gifts by the armful.

articles.headline: New Incidents Test Immunity to Terrorism on U.S. Soil
articles.snippet: The rampage in Fort Hood, Tex., and the account of Virginia men who went to Pakistan challenge the idea that U.S. Muslims are less vulnerable to radicalization than those in Europe.
articles.abstract: The rampage in Fort Hood, Tex., and the account of Virginia men who went to Pakistan challenge the idea that U.S. Muslims are less vulnerable to radicalization than those in Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As the years passed after Sept. 11, 2001, without another major attack on American soil and with no sign of hidden terrorist cells, many counterterrorism specialists reached a comforting conclusion: Muslims in the United States were not very vulnerable to radicalization.

articles.headline: Poor Children Likelier to Get Antipsychotics
articles.snippet: Some children from poor families may be receiving powerful drugs because it is deemed a cheaper way to treat a problem.
articles.abstract: Some children from poor families may be receiving powerful drugs because it is deemed a cheaper way to treat a problem.
articles.lead_paragraph: New federally financed drug research reveals a stark disparity: children covered by Medicaid are given powerful antipsychotic medicines at a rate four times higher than children whose parents have private insurance. And the Medicaid children are more likely to receive the drugs for less severe conditions than their middle-class counterparts, the data shows.

articles.headline: Legal Battles Over E-Book Rights to Older Books
articles.snippet: The ownership of the e-book rights to older titles is a growing source of conflict in the publishing industry.
articles.abstract: The ownership of the e-book rights to older titles is a growing source of conflict in the publishing industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: William Styron may have been one of the leading literary lions of recent decades, but his books are not selling much these days. Now his family has a plan to lure digital-age readers with e-book versions of titles like “Sophie’s Choice,” “The Confessions of Nat Turner” and Mr. Styron’s memoir of depression, “Darkness Visible.”

articles.headline: Can Nokia Recapture Its Glory Days?
articles.snippet: The cellphone maker is losing ground to iPhones and BlackBerrys and recently posted its first quarterly loss in more than a decade.
articles.abstract: The cellphone maker is losing ground to iPhones and BlackBerrys and recently posted its first quarterly loss in more than a decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: HELSINKI, Finland

articles.headline: Interest Rates Are Low, but Banks Balk at Refinancing
articles.snippet: Banks that once handed out home loans freely are now imposing such stringent requirements that many homeowners who might want to refinance are effectively locked out.
articles.abstract: Banks that once handed out home loans freely are now imposing such stringent requirements that many homeowners who might want to refinance are effectively locked out.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mortgage rates in the United States have dropped to their lowest levels since the 1940s, thanks to a trillion-dollar intervention by the federal government. Yet the banks that once handed out home loans freely are imposing such stringent requirements that many homeowners who might want to refinance are effectively locked out.

articles.headline: Get Ready, Get Set, Point Fingers
articles.snippet: Now that Wall Street’s mortgage machinery is pretty much shuttered, details are emerging about how it actually operated. The revelations aren’t pretty.
articles.abstract: Now that Wall Street’s mortgage machinery is pretty much shuttered, details are emerging about how it actually operated. The revelations aren’t pretty.
articles.lead_paragraph: DURING the lending mania, as Wall Street’s mortgage machinery hummed and the money poured in, millions of loans were bought and sold, zipping across town or around the world.

articles.headline: Menopause, as Brought to You by Big Pharma
articles.snippet: Lawsuits and internal documents show how Pfizer and its predecessors promoted the idea of taking hormone drugs.
articles.abstract: Lawsuits and internal documents show how Pfizer and its predecessors promoted the idea of taking hormone drugs.
articles.lead_paragraph: MILLIONS of American women in the 1990s were told they could help their bodies ward off major illness by taking menopausal hormone drugs. Some medical associations said so. Many gynecologists and physicians said so. Respected medical journals said so, too.
articles.byline: By Natasha Singer and Duff Wilson

articles.headline: Building a Baby, With Few Ground Rules
articles.snippet: Surrogacy is largely without regulation, creating an emerging commercial market for babies that raises vexing ethical questions.
articles.abstract: Surrogacy is largely without regulation, creating an emerging commercial market for babies that raises vexing ethical questions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Unable to have a baby of her own, Amy Kehoe became her own general contractor to manufacture one. For Ms. Kehoe and her husband, Scott, the idea seemed like their best hope after years of infertility.

articles.headline: Paul A. Samuelson, Economist, Dies at 94
articles.snippet: The first American Nobel laureate in economics was the foremost academic economist of the 20th century.
articles.abstract: The first American Nobel laureate in economics was the foremost academic economist of the 20th century.
articles.lead_paragraph: Paul A. Samuelson, the first American Nobel laureate in economics and the foremost academic economist of the 20th century, died Sunday at his home in Belmont, Mass. He was 94.

articles.headline: With a New Phone, Google May Challenge Apple
articles.snippet: Google plans to begin selling its unlocked smartphone early next year, a move that could challenge Apple’s leadership in the market.
articles.abstract: Google plans to begin selling its unlocked smartphone early next year, a move that could challenge Apple’s leadership in the market.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Two titans of the tech world, Google and Apple, may soon be engaged in hand-to-hand combat. Or, more precisely, handset-to-handset combat.

articles.headline: As Prices Fall, Blu-ray Players Are Invited Home
articles.snippet: Analysts predict that sales will be up 112 percent over last year, one of the true bright spots in retailing this holiday season.
articles.abstract: Analysts predict that sales will be up 112 percent over last year, one of the true bright spots in retailing this holiday season.
articles.lead_paragraph: Blu-ray, a high-definition variation of the DVD format introduced three years ago, was initially met by a collective shrug from most consumers. Who needed another black box to connect to the TV, the thinking went, even if it did promise to play movie discs in clear, crisp high-definition?

articles.headline: Under Murdoch, Tilting Rightward at The Journal
articles.snippet: There are growing indications in the news pages that Rupert Murdoch, a lifelong conservative, is looking to use The Wall Street Journal to play politics.
articles.abstract: There are growing indications in the news pages that Rupert Murdoch, a lifelong conservative, is looking to use The Wall Street Journal to play politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sunday was the second anniversary of the sale of The Wall Street Journal to Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation. At that time, a chorus of journalism church ladies (I was among them) warned that one of the crown jewels of American journalism now resided in the hands of a roughneck, and predicted that he would use it to his own ends.

articles.headline: Paramount Pictures Finds Long-Sought Balance
articles.snippet: After cutting back the number of pictures it makes and concentrating on some blockbuster franchises, Paramount, led by Brad Grey, is where it wants to be.
articles.abstract: After cutting back the number of pictures it makes and concentrating on some blockbuster franchises, Paramount, led by Brad Grey, is where it wants to be.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  At 3:08 last Monday afternoon, a handful of workers on storm-soaked walks at the Paramount Pictures lot here saw something unlikely: A double rainbow arched over the executive building.

articles.headline: Viruses That Leave Victims Red in the Facebook
articles.snippet: Viruses are rampaging through social networking sites, sending out humiliating messages to friends and followers.
articles.abstract: Viruses are rampaging through social networking sites, sending out humiliating messages to friends and followers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  It used to be that computer viruses attacked only your hard drive. Now they attack your dignity.

articles.headline: Big Risk in a One-Man Brand Like Tiger Woods
articles.snippet: Accenture ended its sponsorship of Tiger Woods, showing that in advertising as in sports, there are no sure things.
articles.abstract: Accenture ended its sponsorship of Tiger Woods, showing that in advertising as in sports, there are no sure things.
articles.lead_paragraph: Accenture, the giant consulting firm, ended its six-year marketing relationship with Tiger Woods on Sunday, showing once again that in advertising as in sports, there are no sure things.

articles.headline: Citigroup Nears Deal to Return Billions in Bailout Funds
articles.snippet: The bank was close to a deal to be the last of the big banks to exit the bailout, after trying to persuade regulators that it was sound enough to stand on its own.
articles.abstract: The bank was close to a deal to be the last of the big banks to exit the bailout, after trying to persuade regulators that it was sound enough to stand on its own.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Citigroup was close to a deal on Sunday night to be the last of the big Wall Street banks to exit the government’s bailout program, after trying to persuade regulators that it was sound enough to stand on its own.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Wells Fargo to Repay U.S., a Coda to the Bailout Era
articles.snippet: Hours after Citigroup reached a deal to exit the Troubled Asset Relief Program, Wells Fargo said it would return $25 billion in federal aid.
articles.abstract: Hours after Citigroup reached a deal to exit the Troubled Asset Relief Program, Wells Fargo said it would return $25 billion in federal aid.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Washington pressed the nation’s largest banks to take billions in federal support last autumn, few protested more loudly than Wells Fargo. On Monday, Wells became the last of the big lenders to rush through a repayment before the end of the year, signifying a fitting bookend to the bailout era.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Andrew Martin

articles.headline: In Exxon Deal, Signs of the New Gusher
articles.snippet: The acquisition of XTO by Exxon is a bet on natural gas, a fossil fuel with reserves that are expanding in hard-to-reach areas.
articles.abstract: The acquisition of XTO by Exxon is a bet on natural gas, a fossil fuel with reserves that are expanding in hard-to-reach areas.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the last decade, a handful of the nation’s small energy companies pulled off a coup. Right under the noses of the industry’s biggest players, they discovered huge amounts of natural gas in fields stretching from Texas to Pennsylvania.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Clifford Krauss
